description:
Organisations with ten or more employees can now sign up for asymptomatic workplace testing as part of an enhanced drive to identify emerging COVID-19 cases and break chains of transmissions. Free lateral flow device tests have been made more widely available as the country emerges from lockdown restrictions and moves beyond level 0. The testing regime is voluntary and organisations can adopt an LFD Collect model to distribute among workers or implement their own asymptomatic test site model in workplace
Workplace testing in Scotland had previously been targeted at prioritised areas of the public sector, critical national infrastructure and private businesses with high transmission rates.

description: Scotland's first community testing site for people without symptoms to get tested for coronavirus (COVID-19) has opened in Johnstone, Renfrewshire on the 02 December 2020. Up to 12,000 asymptomatic residents will be able to be tested at the drop-in test site, located at Johnstone Town hall, over the next eight days. Residents will be testing using lateral flow devices, which can give people their results in around 45 minutes. Any positive cases will then be confirmed by PCR test. UPDATE: Scotland's next community testing site for people without COVID-19 symptoms will open in Cowdenbeath, Fife  on 10 February 2021. The centre will open from 8am to 8pm Monday to Friday and, initially, from 11am to 5pm Saturday and Sunday. Four more sites in different areas across Fife will open in the coming weeks. The sites will provide lateral flow testing, followed by a confirmatory PCR test if the first result is positive. Dedicated support will be available on-site for anyone who needs help to self-isolate as a result, including advice on how to access financial support and food packages.

description: From 18 February, anyone who is identified as a close contact of somebody who has tested positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) will be asked to get tested. This approach does not replace self-isolation in any way, and close contacts who test negative will still have to complete 10 days of self-isolation. Close contacts who test positive will be asked to self-isolate for a further 10 days from the time of their test result, to ensure they are no longer infectious when they leave self-isolation.

description: From late February, regular testing will be offered to support the return to schools and nurseries. Senior phase secondary school students, and all staff in primary, secondary, and special schools, including school-based ELC staff, will be able to benefit from routine at-home testing two times a week. Certain workplaces where the risk of transmission is greater and which provide essential or critical services, such as those within the food processing and distribution sectors and staff within emergency service control rooms, will also be supported to introduce routine workforce testing.

description: Scotland's first community testing site for people without symptoms to get tested for coronavirus (COVID-19) has opened in Johnstone, Renfrewshire on the 02 December 2020. Up to 12,000 asymptomatic residents will be able to be tested at the drop-in test site, located at Johnstone Town hall, over the next eight days. Residents will be testing using lateral flow devices, which can give people their results in around 45 minutes. Any positive cases will then be confirmed by PCR test. UPDATE: As of March 4, there are 24 asymptomatic test sites providing COVID-19 testing for people without symptoms in targeted areas. A further 24 sites across Scotland are set to open over the next month. Nine Mobile Testing Units are also currently deployed to provide community testing for local residents, whether they have symptoms or not.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Food production and processing businesses are being urged to sign up for routine staff testing to help identify cases of coronavirus (COVID-19), keep workforces safe and break chains of transmission. Free lateral flow antigen test kits are available to eligible businesses which are essential to maintaining an adequate supply of food for the nation, and where outbreak risks can be higher due to the working environment such as abattoirs, meat and seafood processing facilities and dairies, as well as food distribution businesses. This is particularly targeted at larger (over 25 employees) higher risk food processing businesses such as abattoirs, meat and seafood processing and dairies where, despite mitigations already in place, a combination of low temperatures, limited ventilation, low light high humidity can facilitate spread of the virus and lead to outbreaks as well as food distribution businesses where the loss of a facility due to an outbreak could lead to impacts on food supply by reducing supplies to retail or hindering exports.

description: Rapid lateral flow test kits will be mailed from 14 June 2021 to all visitors to the Glasgow Fan Zone to encourage testing. 17,000 ticket holders due attend the UEFA EURO 2020 Fan Zone at Glasgow Green will be contacted. In addition, a mobile testing bus is also now at Glasgow Green to provide on-site lateral flow testing, while attendees may be asked by COVID marshals on site whether they have taken a test as part of ongoing reporting on the site.

description: On the 4th June 2020, the UK Transport Secretary announced that, from the 15th June 2020, face coverings will be mandatory while using public transport in England, including buses, coaches, trains, ferries, and aircraft. There will be exceptions for very young children, disabled people, and those with breathing difficulties.The government advises people to avoid public transport where possible. Public transport operators will be able to refuse travel or issue penalty fines for those who fail to wear a face covering. British Transport Police will also support the implementation of these changes.

description: From 13 July, people in Scotland are advised against travelling to North West England. Travel between Scotland and Greater Manchester, East Lancashire and parts of West Yorkshire should only be undertaken if absolutely essential. UPDATE: Measures to suppress the spread of the Coronavirus (COVID-19) have been supported in a debate and vote in Scottish parliament today. Regulations prevent people who live in a Level 3 or Level 4 area from travelling outside their local authority except for an essential purpose will also come into force. The regulations also prevent non-essential travel into a Level 3 or 4 local authority area, except for the same reasons. The changes to protection levels will remain in place for three weeks until December 11. This includes Level 4 Local Authority Areas in East Ayrshire, East Dunbartonshire, East Renfrewshire, Glasgow, North Lanarkshire and Renfrewshire and Level 3 Local Auhtority Areas in Angus, Clackmannanshire, Dundee City, Edinburgh, Falkirk, Fife, Inverclyde, North Ayrshire, Perth and Kinross as well as East Lothian and Midlothian until November 24.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In England (UK), on 26th March, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020 came into effect. From this, no person may leave the place where they are living without reasonable excuse. Reasonable excuses include: obtaining basic necessities like food and medicines, essential supplies, and money, for those in the same household or for vulnerable people; taking exercise alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance; to donate blood; to travel for the purposes of work or volunteering, where it is not reasonably possible for that person to work from home; to attend a family member or friend’s funeral; to fulfil a legal obligation, like attending court; to access critical public services including childcare and educational facilities, social services, and services provided to victims; letting children continue to live between separated parents’ households; religious leaders going to their places of worship; to move house were reasonably necessary; to avoid injury or illness or to escape from risk of harm. This restriction does not apply to any person who is homeless.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In England (UK), on 26th March, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020 came into effect. From this, no person may leave the place where they are living without reasonable excuse. Reasonable excuses include: obtaining basic necessities like food and medicines, essential supplies, and money, for those in the same household or for vulnerable people; taking exercise alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance; to donate blood; to travel for the purposes of work or volunteering, where it is not reasonably possible for that person to work from home; to attend a family member or friend’s funeral; to fulfil a legal obligation, like attending court; to access critical public services including childcare and educational facilities, social services, and services provided to victims; letting children continue to live between separated parents’ households; religious leaders going to their places of worship; to move house were reasonably necessary; to avoid injury or illness or to escape from risk of harm. This restriction does not apply to any person who is homeless. UPDATE: The Prime Minister made a statement on the 10th May. Regarding work, he Said "We said that you should work from home if you can, and only go to work if you must. We now need to stress that anyone who can’t work from home, for instance those in construction or manufacturing, should be actively encouraged to go to work. And we want it to be safe for you to get to work. So you should avoid public transport if at all possible – because we must and will maintain social distancing, and capacity will therefore be limited. So work from home if you can, but you should go to work if you can’t work from home. And to ensure you are safe at work we have been working to establish new guidance for employers to make workplaces COVID-secure. And when you do go to work, if possible do so by car or even better by walking or bicycle. But just as with workplaces, public transport operators will also be following COVID-secure standards". Regarding outdoor exercise and leisure, he said "And from this Wednesday, we want to encourage people to take more and even unlimited amounts of outdoor exercise. You can sit in the sun in your local park, you can drive to other destinations, you can even play sports but only with members of your own household. You must obey the rules on social distancing and to enforce those rules we will increase the fines for the small minority who break them".
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
In Scotland, businesses and the public will be required, by law, to follow social distancing measures. It will be a criminal office to flout social distance guidance. Police Scotland will be able to issue penalty notices of £60 , reduced to to £30 if paid within 28 days, where they have reason to believe there has been an offence under the regulations. These penalties are doubled for each repeat offence up to a £960 cap, with no reduction for early payment. People in Scotland are being asked to only go outside if they have a 'reasonable excuse'. These including shopping for necessary food, household and medical supplies, travelling to and from work where working from home is not possible, and daily exercise. Enforcement can be used against businesses and venues that have been told to close.

Due tot he exceptional nature of these powers, these regulations will be reviewed at least every 21 days to ensure they are still necessary.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: On April 24th, the government of Northern Ireland eased a few restrictions of the lockdown and decided to open up cemeteries as long as social distancing is practiced. Additionally, they began to allow reasonable travel for exercise.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: For May 11, Scotland advises that people can go outside more than once a day to exercise. This activity should continue to be undertaken close to home. Those going out to exercise should either go alone or with members of their household. The change does not allow people to mix with people from different households, to gather in groups, or to go out to relax outdoors.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: As of May 12th, a five-stage plan for easing the COVID-19 lockdown in Northern Ireland has been published by the executive. Phase one encourages those unable to work from home to return to work on a phased basis, allows opening of large outdoor-based retail  including garden centres, though associated cafes and restaurants can only offer takeaway or collection, allows groups of four to six people who do not share a household to meet outdoors maintaining social distancing, allows visits to immediate family indoors where social distancing is possible unless people are shielding, allows for opening of drive-through church services and churches for private prayer, with appropriate social distancing and cleaning of shared contact hard surfaces, and allows outdoor spaces, public sport amenities, and drive-through cinemas to open.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:

Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: As of May 12th, a five-stage plan for easing the COVID-19 lock down in Northern Ireland has been published by the executive. During phase two, non-food retail can open where numbers are limited with social distancing, groups of up to 10 can meet outdoors, as demand increases on public transport within social distancing requirements, people are encouraged to walk and cycle for short journeys where possible, team sports training on a non-contact basis in small groups can resume, selected libraries can reopen with restricted services, and open-air museums can re-open.

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: As of May 12th, a five-stage plan for easing the COVID-19 lockdown in Northern Ireland has been published by the executive. During phase four, "contact" retail (hairdressers, fitness studios, tattoo and piercing parlours) can open subject to mitigations following risk assessment, schools can expand provision to accommodate all pupils on part-time basis with combination of in-school and remote learning, demand for public transport will be reduced and staggered at peak times through continued home working and staggered start times for businesses, a wider range of gatherings will be permitted including church services subject to social distancing and other suitable mitigations, such as cleaning of hard surfaces, competitive sport "behind closed doors" or with limitations on the number of spectators can resume, leisure centres and other indoor leisure facilities can open, and outdoor concerts can resume on a restricted basis.

During phase 5 (the final phase), all will be able to return to work subject to mitigations, remote working will still be strongly encouraged, hospitality retail (restaurants, cafes, pubs) can open subject to risk assessment, initially on a limited basis, early-year school provision can be expanded to full-time basis, public transport will be operating full service but subject to ongoing risk assessment, people can meet in extended groups subject to social distancing, close physical contact sports can resume, there can be return to competitive sport and full use of sporting facilities, spectators can attend live events on a restricted basis, and nightclubs, concerts will open on a limited basis.

update_level_var: Volume of policy relaxing ; [compliance] of policy relaxing
description: Scotland to introduce lockdown with a ban on gatherings of more than two people from 23 March 2020. UPDATE: Scotland to ease lockdown from 29 May 2020. From 29 May 2020, one household can now meet up with another outdoors. This can be in one household’s garden, but physical distancing is still required. It is expected households will only meet one other household within the same day and up to a recommended maximum of eight people in the overall group. Additionally, people in Scotland cantravel short distances for outdoor leisure and exercise but should remain in your local area, suggested to be five miles from your house, although we ask people to use their judgement. From 29 May 2020,public outdoor spaces can now be used for recreational purposes, for example to sit in a park, sunbathe or have a picnic. People should not share food and drink between households and should avoid using shared facilities, such as bathrooms. If eating, each household should bring their own food separately and avoid sharing utensils, dishes or cups and use a hand sanitiser before eating. Physical distancing between households should be maintained at all times.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On the 30th June 2020 in the UK, the Health Secretary announced that, after a rise in COVID-19 cases in the city, Leicester is to be placed under a full local lockdown. Non-essential shops had shut, and schools close for most children. He advised that people in Leicester “stay at home as much as you can”, and recommended against all but essential travel to, from and within Leicester. He said the new local measures would be in place for at least two weeks, but kept under constant review.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
Following a cluster of cases in the Anna and Gretna areas of Dumfries and Galloway, restrictions to the distance people can travel for leisure purposes are to remain in place. People in Scotland living in the postcode areas of DG16 (Gretna), DG12 (Anna), DG1 and DG2 (Drumfries), DG11 (Lockerbie), DG13 (Langholm) and DG14 (Canonbie) are being asked to travel no more than 5 miles while effort to manage the outbreak continue. This does not apply to essential travel.
Holiday makers from other areas who have booked self-catering accommodation in these postcodes are still able to take up their reservations but must adhere to these travel restrictions once they arrive. Visits to care homes in these postcode areas will not be permitted over the weekend.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As of March 2020, individuals with existing medical conditions that put them at the highest clinical risk of severe illness from COVID-19 stringently self-isolate, or 'shield', for an initial 12-week period until the 18th of June. UPDATE: From 10 July, those shielding will no longer need to physically distance from people they live with. They can meet in groups of up to eight people outdoors from two other households in a single day, as long as strict hand hygiene and physical distancing advice is followed. Those who have been advised to shield will also be able to travel further than 5 miles from their house, book places to stay, such as self-catering accommodation without shared facilities, and use toilets in other people's houses if they are meeting them indoors. Those currently shielding and living alone can also form an 'extended household group' with one other household which means that those shielding can visit one other household indoors and stay overnight without physical distancing.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: People with certain health conditions (please note which health conditions in the text entry)

description: Scotland to introduce lockdown with a ban on gatherings of more than two people from 23 March 2020. UPDATE: Form 10 July, up to three households will be able to meet indoors- up to a maximum of eight people. Meanwhile, up to five different households to a maximum of 15 people will be able to meet outdoors. A household can meet up to four other households per day in total. Two metre distancing between households should continue with heightened hygiene measures.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: People in hospital who do not have coronavirus will be able to have a designated visitor from 15 July 2020. All hospital visitors must arrange a time to visit in advance with ward staff, not visit any other patient in the hospital and must not bring anything with them (such as food), adhere to strict hand hygiene and face covering guidance, maintain strict physical distancing in communal areas of hospital and not visit anyone in hospital if they have symptoms suggestive of COVID-19
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Following an increase in coronavirus cases in Aberdeen, local restrictions on travel, indoor gatherings between households and the closure of indoor and outdoor hospitality will be introduced in the Aberdeen City local authority area from 5pm August 5.

Bars, restaurants, cafes and pubs will be required to close. Hotel restaurants may remain open to provide food for existing guests and takeaway services can continue. People in Aberdeen City are asked not to meet other households indoors or travel more than five miles for leisure or recreational purposes. People can continue to travel for work, or education purposes. Indoor visits to hospitals and care homes should be limited to essential visits only. Outdoor visits to care homes are permitted by one designated person, in line with current guidance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Following an increase in coronavirus cases in Aberdeen, local restrictions on travel, indoor gatherings between households and the closure of indoor and outdoor hospitality will be introduced in the Aberdeen City local authority area from 5pm August 5.

Bars, restaurants, cafes and pubs will be required to close. Hotel restaurants may remain open to provide food for existing guests and takeaway services can continue. People in Aberdeen City are asked not to meet other households indoors or travel more than five miles for leisure or recreational purposes. People can continue to travel for work, or education purposes. Indoor visits to hospitals and care homes should be limited to essential visits only. Outdoor visits to care homes are permitted by one designated person, in line with current guidance. UPDATE: From 24 August, the five mile travel limit, restrictions on gatherings and limitations on hospital and care home visits will be lifted in Aberdeen. Businesses, excluding hospitality business, will be able to reopen on the 24 August too, with hospitality businesses reopening 26 August once an environmental health check ahs been completed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From midnight of the 01 September 2020, people in Glasgow, East Renfrewshire and West Dunbartonshire local authority areas should not meet with people from other households in indoor household setting. Members of different households can continue to meet outdoors, including in gardens and hospitality setting. Indoor visits to hospitals can care homes will be limited to essential visits and outdoor visits to care homes are permitted by three people from a maximum of two households. Those households who have formed an extended households and people providing care and support can continue to meet indoors with enhanced hygiene measures. These restrictions will be introduced for an initial two week period.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From midnight of the 01 September 2020, people in Glasgow, East Renfrewshire and West Dunbartonshire local authority areas should not meet with people from other households in indoor household setting. These restrictions will be introduced for an initial two week period. UPDATE: Restrictions on meetings in indoor household settings are to be extended to people living Renfrewshire and East Dunbartonshire. The current limits on indoor gatherings for people living in Glasgow, East Renfrewshire and West Dunbartonshire will continue for at least a further seven days. From midnight 07 September 2020, the revised restrictions are: people in the Glasgow, East Renfrewshire, West Dunbartonshire, Renfrewshire and East Dunbartonshire local authority areas should not meet with people from other households in indoor household settings. People from these areas should not people in indoor household setting and indoor visits to hospitals and care homes will continue will be limited to essential visits only.

description: From 23 October, the Scottish government is not permitted people from any other households, including children, into individual's home or another person's home socially, unless they are part of an extended household. Exemptions applies for children who parents do not live in the same household and there is very limited exemptions for childcare and tradespeople. A maximum of six people from two households can meet in outdoor spaces or public indoor spaces, with under-12s not being included in this count.

description:
A series of new protection levels have been introduced to determine restrictions and lockdowns across Scotland. These levels range from 0-4.
In Level 4 area, a max of 4 people from up to 2 household may socialise indoor in a public place or outdoors- there is no in-house socialising. Individuals are not allowed to leave their local authority area  or public transport unless travelling for a permitted reason.
In Level 3 areas, a max of 6 people from up to 2 household may socialise indoor in a public place - there is no in-house socialising- a max of 6 people from up to 6 households may socialise outdoors. There is unrestricted travel to all Level 3 area but no travel to level 0-2 or 4 unless for a permitted reason.
In Level 2 areas, a max of 6 people from up to 3 households may socialise indoor in a public place, 3 people from 2 households in-house and up to 8 people from up to 8 households may socialise outdoors. There is unrestricted travel between all 0-2 areas but no travel to level 3 or 4 unless for a permitted reason.
In Level 1 areas, a max of 8 people from up to 3 households may socialise indoors in a public place, 6 people from 3 households in-house and up to 12 people from up to 12 households may socialise outdoors. 
In Level 0 areas, a max of 10 people from up to 4 households may socialise indoors in a public place, 8 people from 4 households in-house and up to 15 people from 15 household may socialise outdoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

Level 3: Inverclyde, East Dunbartonshire, West Dunbartonshire, Renfrewshire, East Renfrewshire, City of Glasgow, South Ayrshire, East Eyrshire, North Ayrshire, Stirling, Falkirk, Clackmannanshire, City of Edinburgh, Midlothian, West Lothian, East Lothian, Dundee, North Lanarkshire and South Lanarkshire.

description:
The Scottish Government has agreed to a cautious and limited relaxation on household meetings to support people over the Christmas period. A maximum of three holds are to be able to meet in a "bubble" during a short window of time across the festive period. Households will be able to travel between local authorities and between the four nations during December 23 and 27 to form a bubble, and must only join one bubble. The five-day period provides time for travel, and for those who may have to work over Christmas. Households are not required to use all five days and should keep visits to no more than one or two days if possible. Everyone is asked to consider very carefully whether the opportunity to mix for a few days is necessary given the risk of spreading the virus. 

The specific guidelines of this approach states that: a "bubble" should be formed household to household only (i.e.: different people in a household should not pick their own bubble); between 23 and 27 December, people can meet in an exclusive "bubble" composed of three households; in all other settings (e.g.: hospitality, entertainment venues) those who have formed a bubble must only socialise with members of their own household; and households deciding to form a bubble will be advised to limit social contact before and after the period of relaxation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

In addition, Barra and Vatersay will move into lockdown from 00:01 on 20 Jan 2021 following a sharp increase in infection rates. The rest of Comhairle nan Eilean Siar will remain in level 3. Nobody who lives in an area under lockdown should leave or remain outside their home except for an essential purpose like caring responsibilities, outdoor exercise and work that cannot be done from home.

description:
The Welsh government announced adjustments to current lockdown conditions:

From 20 February, 4 people from 2 different households can meet outdoors for socially distanced local exercise. This doesn’t apply to private gardens.

From 22 Februrary, children between the ages of 3 to 7 can return to schools via a phased approach, while vocational learners that require practical learning can attend college.

From March 1, licensed wedding venues (such as visitor attractions and hotels) can re-open - but only to perform wedding and civil partnership ceremonies.

description: From 23 October, the Scottish government is not permitted people from any other households, including children, into individual's home or another person's home socially, unless they are part of an extended household. Exemptions applies for children who parents do not live in the same household and there is very limited exemptions for childcare and tradespeople. A maximum of six people from two households can meet in outdoor spaces or public indoor spaces, with under-12s not being included in this count. UPDATE: Travel within Scotland for outdoor socialising, recreation and exercise will be allowed from April 16. People must continue to Stay Local for other purposes such as non-essential shopping and public transport capacity will continue to be limited. Outdoor meetings in groups of up to six adults from up to six households will also be allowed from April 16, with under-12s not counting towards this limit. Socialising in homes is still not permitted.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Measures no longer necessary to support the ongoing public health response will be removed from the Scottish Coronavirus Acts after Parliament approved their expiration. The Coronavirus (Extension and Expiry) (Scotland) Bill was voted for by MSPs after three days of scrutiny. Measures expired by the legislation include:
			i. Emergency operational measures in respect of Children's Hearings and child protection to ensure that children's rights have been protected throughout this period
			ii. 'stop the clock' measures on the duration of guardianship orders and certificates authorising medical treatment for adults with incapacity, as the normal systems for processing these resume
			iii. Power to accelerate scrutiny of regulations
			iv. Power to prevent the public attending in person local authority meetings and alcohol licensing hearings
			v. Admissibility of evidence by statement
This legislation extends other measures beyond the original expiry data of 30 September 2021 to 31 March 2022 to enable public authorities to continue to operate. Temporary measures to enable the court system to operate in these challenging times, measures to keep businesses and public services running and temporary changes to the law for debtors and tenants facing financial hardship will be continued. It adds report on the evictions and tenants' rights to existing bi-monthly requirements on the Scottish Government. A one-off reporting requirement has been added on wedding and civil partn
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
The Scottish Government is inviting views on the draft aims and principles of an independent public inquiry into the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 Inquiry Establishment Aims and Principles paper is intended to shape its terms of reference with input from stakeholders, including bereaved families. The proposed inquiry would be established by the end of the year, to scrutinise decisions taken in the course of this pandemic, and learn lessons for future pandemics. It would take a person-centred, human rights based approach with a focus on outcomes and timely reporting to identify lessons and recommendations. Particular consideration would also be given to the 'four harms' of the pandemic: direct health impacts of COVID-19, including cases and deaths in cares homes; other non COVID health impacts; societal impacts, including education; and economic impacts.
The public are now encouraged to share their ideas and comments on the suggested approach via email by 30 September.

description: On 2 April 2020, the Scottish Government has outlined details of the improved process to report COVID-19 deaths that began today, Thursday April 2. Health Protection Scotland (HPS) has worked with National Records of Scotland (NRS) to put the new, more efficient procedure in place, which involves cross-checking records between HPS and NRS to identify individuals who have died and have a laboratory confirmed report of COVID-19. As part of this new system, 40 deaths, which would not yet have been reported under the old system – because next of kin had not been informed - have been included and allocated to the last three days as appropriate.  There is no change in the definition used to report deaths of COVID-19, which is defined as an individual who has died and has had a laboratory confirmed report of COVID-19 in the 28 days prior to death
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: Change in Health Reporting Processes

description: On the 10th May 2020 in the UK, prime minister Boris Johnson announces a threat level alert system. The system will use a scale of one to five. The threat level system to be introduced will apply to England only. It is understood the system - with alerts ranging from green (level one) to red (level five) - will be adjusted according to data and will be similar to the one used to keep the public informed about the terror threat level. In his address, Mr Johnson is expected to say England is currently at stage four but moving towards stage three.

description: Test and Protect – NHS Scotland’s approach to controlling the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) in the community – will be rolled out across all health boards from Thursday, May 28. From that date, everyone aged five and over who has COVID-19 symptoms of a new continuous cough, temperature or loss or change in sense of taste or smell should go to NHS Inform online or call 0800 028 2816 to book a test. Under the system, people will need to isolate with their household as soon as they have symptoms and, if they have a positive test result, they will be asked to provide details of all recent close contacts to NHS contact tracers.  Those people will be contacted and asked to isolate for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: Test and protect policy announced whereby people will need to isolate with their household as soon as they have symptoms of coronavirus and, if they have a positive test result, they will be asked to provide details of all recent close contacts to NHS contact tracers. Those people will be contacted and asked to isolate for 14 days.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On the 1st June 2020 in England, UK, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (Amendment) (No. 3) Regulations 2020 came into force. The restriction not allowing people to leave home without reasonable excuse is replaced with the restriction that someone cannot stay overnight at any place that they don’t live without a reasonable excuse. Reasonable excuses include: attending a funeral; elite athlete training and competition; in the process of moving house; for work, voluntary, and charity purposes; to provide care and assistance to a vulnerable person; to provide emergency assistance; to avoid injury or illness, or to escape a risk of harm; to obtain medical assistance; to fulfil a legal obligation; children living among family; if a person is unable to return to their home. This does not apply to anyone who is homeless.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: Individuals are not allowed to stay anywhere outside of their home overnight.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On the 13th June 2020 in the United Kingdom, part of the The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (Amendment) (No. 4) Regulations 2020 came into force.Linked households, also referred to support bubbles, are introduced. No person may leave their household or linked household without reasonable excuse. Persons in linked households are permitted to have a public gathering together. A linked household is where a household comprises one adult, or one adult and one or more persons who are under the age of 18 on 12th June 2020 (“the first household”), the adult may choose to be linked with one other household (“the second household”), provided that the second household is not linked with any other household and all the adult members of the second household agree.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: Linked households (also called support bubbles) are introduced.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On the 3rd July 2020, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions)(Leicester) Regulations 2020 were rushed through parliament. These regulations came into effect on the 4th July 2020. These regulations apply in relationship to England only, specifically the areas in and around the city of Leicester. This is the first local lockdown in the UK.Places of worship in Leicester must be closed, except for funerals, to broadcast acts of worship, to provide essential voluntary/public services (food banks, blood donation etc.), to provide childcare, or for private prayer. Community centres in Leicester must close, except to provide essential voluntary/public services or provide childcare.Crematoriums in Leicester must close to the public, except for funerals or burials.People or businesses that repeatedly flout the new law could be fined up to £3,200 (£100 for first offence). Police are to enforce these restrictions. Fines are not imposed to people under 18 years old.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: Closure of places of worship, community centres, and crematoriums
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On the 3rd July 2020, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions)(Leicester) Regulations 2020 were rushed through parliament. These regulations came into effect on the 4th July 2020. These regulations apply in relationship to England only, specifically the areas in and around the city of Leicester. This is the first local lockdown in the UK.No person who lives in Leicester may, without reasonable excuse, stay overnight at any place other than the place where they are living or where their linked household is living. No person who lives outside Leicester may, without reasonable excuse, stay overnight at any place within the protected area other than the place where their linked household is living. People or businesses that repeatedly flout the new law could be fined up to £3,200 (£100 for first offence). Police are to enforce these restrictions. Fines are not imposed to people under 18 years old.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: Restriction on movement
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: The Scottish Government has announced that a new national helpline is being set up to provide essential assistance to those who don’t have a network of support but who are at high risk of contracting COVID-19. The service – which opens April 14 2020 – will offer help to those who do not have family or existing community support and cannot get online and who are over 70, disabled, require the support of mental health services, are pregnant or receive a flu jab for health reasons. This service is in addition to localised support already available for people who have received letters advising them to shield themselves. However, any of those in the shielding category who are not yet receiving assistance, who do not have family and cannot get online can access support via this new helpline. It will initially operate during core working hours of 09:00 to 17:00 whilst plans are developed and implemented to extend it to operate for a longer period each day.

description: The Protect Scotland app, NHS Scotland's new contact tracing app, is now available to download for free via Apple and Google stores. The app uses Bluetooth technology to anonymously alert users if they have been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19, and advises them to self-isolate. Users of the app who test positive will still get a call from a contact tracer to confirm their details and who they have been in close contact with.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Gathering information related to COVID-19 from the public
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: People who have downloaded the Protect Scotland app will now able to continue using it if they travel to England and Wales, as well as Gibraltar. Scotland has developed its own 'federated server' which allow for all proximity apps within the UK, Crown Dependencies and Gibraltar to work with each for the first time. From Nov 5 2020, the second phase of this interoperability means that Protect Scotland will continue working when people are required to travel for essential reasons to England, Wales and Gibraltar.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The Scottish Government's recently refreshed Ready Scotland website (ready.scot) provides a range of information for anyone looking for support during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, as well as advice on preparing for winter weather. It also provides guidance for those who wish to help out those around them, whether on an individual basis or through volunteering with local community groups and charities

description: The Scottish Government has launched a new campaign encouraging people to get vaccinated for COVID-19 as soon as they are eligible launches 21 Jan 2021. The 'Roll your sleeves up' campaign will emphasise the importance of the vaccine and its safety, as well as the prioritisation list set out by Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) to ensure those most at risk are vaccinated first.

description:
A new digital service to support businesses in collecting contact details for contact tracing purposes, Check in Scotland, is now available in participating venues. The Check in Scotland service will enable people to quickly and securely provide their contact details by scanning the official Test & Protect Check in Scotland QR code poster via their smartphone camera or by downloading the Check in Scotland app. Any contact details collected will be held in a secure encrypted data store unique to each venue for 21 days. Unless information is requested by public health officials as part of their contact tracing efforts, visitor data is automatically deleted on day 22. Venue and visitor details will not be used for any other purpose.
Businesses that can use Check in Scotland include: pubs, bars, restaurants and cafes; tourism and leisure businesses, such as theme parks, museums and cinemas; close contact services, including hairdressers, barbers, beauticians, tattooists, sports and massage therapists; services run by local councils, such as libraries, leisure centres and registration offices; cremation authorities, burial authorities, places of worship or funeral director service rooms offering funeral services; and places of worship.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On 13 February, Wales advices that all travellers who develop flu-like symptoms however mild, (these symptoms could be a fever, a cough, or difficulty breathing) within 14 days of returning from mainland China, Thailand, Japan, Republic of Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia or Macau, should self-isolate at home immediately and call NHS Direct Wales or 111, if available in their area.

description: Scotland is advising all passengers who have arrived in the UK from Iran, anyone who have visited the special care zones of Daegu and Chengdu in South Korea, the Hubei province in China and specific lockdown areas in Northern Italy as designated by the Italian government including parts of Italy north of Pisa, Florence and Rimini since Feb 19 are advised to self-isolate for 14, even if they don't experience symptoms, and call their GP. Passengers who have arrived in the UK from Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar and Vietnam are also advised to monitor their health and self-isolate if they develop symptoms.

description: Scotland is advising people with symptoms suggestive of coronavirus- such as a continuing cough, a fever or a temperature of above 37.8C- should stay at home for seven days from March 13, Scotland's Chief Medical officer has announced. Those who have been in contact with someone who is experiencing symptoms should only stay at home if they begin to experience symptoms.

description: On March 12, Scotland’s Chief Medical Officer announced that people with symptoms (fever or cough) that can be coronavirus (COVID-19) should stay at home for seven days. Those who have been in contact with other persons experiencing symptoms do not need to stay at home, unless they also develop symptoms. The advice about home-stay takes effect on March 13.

description: As part of Northern Ireland's contact tracing pilot program, released on April 27 2020, “employers are expected to support self-isolating employees and not require them to attend work.” In this case, self-isolating employees can include those who "have coronavirus symptoms and are awaiting a test result" , "have tested positive for coronavirus","are a member of the same household as someone who has symptoms or has tested positive for coronavirus", or "have been in close recent contact with someone who has tested positive and received a PHA notification to self-isolate."

description: The Prime Minister made a statement on the 10th May 2020. Regarding international travel, he said "to prevent re-infection from abroad, I am serving notice that it will soon be the time – with transmission significantly lower – to impose quarantine on people coming into this country by air".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On the 11th May 2020, the UK government releases their rebuild plan document. With regard to international travel, it stated that: "theGovernment will require all international arrivals to supply their contact and accommodation information", and also that: " the Government will require all international arrivals not on a short list of exemptions toself-isolate in their accommodation for fourteen days on arrival into the UK. Where international travellers are unable to demonstrate where they would self-isolate, they will be required to do so in accommodation arranged by the Government". Following this: "Small exemptions to these measures will be in place to provide for continued security of supply intothe UK and so as not to impede work supporting national security or critical infrastructure and to meet the UK’s international obligations. All journeys within the Common Travel Area will also be exempt from these measures."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: From the 8 June 2020, individuals entering the UK must quarantine and self-isolate for 14 days. Lorry drivers, seasonal farm workers, and coronavirus medics will be exempt. The requirement will also not apply to those travelling from the Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.

description: From the 8 June 2020, individuals entering the UK must quarantine and self-isolate for 14 days. Lorry drivers, seasonal farm workers, and coronavirus medics will be exempt. The requirement will also not apply to those travelling from the Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.UPDATE: On the 27th June 2020 in the UK, ministers announced that Blanket restrictions on non-essential overseas travel will be relaxed in the UK from 6 July. Holidaymakers are expected to be allowed to travel to certain European countries without having to spend 14 days in quarantine when they return. They are thought to include Spain, France, Greece, Italy, the Netherlands, Finland, Belgium, Turkey, Germany and Norway - but not Portugal or Sweden. The full list of travel corridors with the UK would be published the following week. A traffic light system will be introduced - with countries classified as green, amber and red depending on the prevalence of coronavirus. The UK is likely to discuss arrangements with countries over the coming days. UPDATE: People can arrive in the UK from some European countries without having to quarantine for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 3rd of July in England, a full list of countries for which quarantine will not apply to people arriving back in England was published.The prime minister stated that "Instead of quarantining arrivals from the whole world, we will only quarantine arrivals from those countries where the virus is sadly not under control.". Countries including Greece, Spain, France and Belgium were on the list, which came into effect from 10 July.

description: Changes are being made to self-isolation rules for close contacts of COVID cases to allow essential staff in critical roles to return to work to maintain lifeline services and critical national infrastructure. It will be possible to apply to exempt those who work in critical roles where staff shortages are in danger of putting essential services, such as health and social care, transport and the provision of food supplies at risk. Exemption will only be granted in respect of members of staff who voluntarily agree not to self-isolate, and the employers' duty of care to all their employees must be respected. Strict conditions will apply- staff must be double-vaccinated and in receipt of their second dose at least two weeks previously. They will also require to have a negative PCR test and to agree to undertake daily lateral flow tests. Exemptions will be made on a temporary basis and last only for as long as there is an immediate risk to business or service continuity. Applications may be made via the Scottish Government website.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: People who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19,Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: The Scottish Government is telling businesses including cafes, pubs, and restaurants to close, along with nightclubs, theatres, cinemas, gyms, casinos, betting shops, bingo halls, concert halls and leisure centres from 20 March 2020. UPDATE: From 15 July 2020, indoor restaurants, cafes and pubs in Scotland are allowed to re-open. Additionally in Scotland, all holiday accommodation can re-open from 15 July, as well as the childcare sector, hairdressers and barbers. Museums, galleries, cinemas and libraries can also open from 15 July, with strict physical distancing and for many of these facilities advanced ticketing will be required.

UPDATE: Theatre and live music venues will reopen September 14 with physical distancing in place. There will be a limited reopening of sports stadium as of September 14 with a limited number of spectators and physical distancing in place, with some potentially reopening earlier for testing subject of agreement with the government. Soft play facilities will reopen September 14 with guidance in place, including no ball pools and enhanced hygiene. Outdoor-focused standing live events will also reopen September 14 with physical distancing, enhanced hygiene and restricted numbers. Indoor sports courts will now also be allowed to be used by both adults and young people aged 12 and above for contact sports as of September 14. description: In England (UK), on 26th March, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020 came into effect. From this, all premises in which food or drink are sold for consumption on those premises are required to close and to cease selling food or drink for consumption on its premises. This excludes hotels and other accomodation. Businesses selling or hiring goods in a shop, or providing library services must cease to carry on that business or provide that service except by making deliveries or through a website/online communication, telephone, or post. This excludes any business which provides hot or cold food for consumption off the premises.Businesses consisting of the provision of holiday accommodation must cease to carry on that business. However, such a business can provide accommodation to any person who: is unable to return to their main residence; uses that accommodation as their main residence; needs accommodation while moving house or to attend a funeral; otherwise homeless. Such a business can stay open to provide accommodation or support services for the homeless or to host blood donation sessions.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Scotland is requiring all work on construction sites, unless it is for essential projects, should stop immediately as of April 6 2020, as outlined in new guidance for the construction industry. Any project deemed essential can only continue operating if it can comply with guidance on social distance, safety and welfare during the COVID-19 outbreak. Any site unable to meet these requirements should close. 

Essential projects include: those to create or re-purpose facilities which will be used directly in COVID-19 related activities, projects to create or re-purpose facilities which will be used to accommodate key workers, or free up space in facilities to be used directly in COVID-19 related activities. projects which are considered essential public services and the repair and maintenance of critical infrastructure
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

description: On the 13th May 2020 in the UK, the The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (Amendment) (No. 2) Regulations 2020 came into effect. This allowed businesses providing holiday accommodation to provide accommodation for key workers who need accommodation for work purposes. Businesses involved in residential properties are allowed to resume business. Garden centres and outdoor sports courts are allowed to open.

description:
On the 15th June 2020 in the United Kingdom, the provisions of The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (Amendment) (No. 4) Regulations 2020 which hadn’t come into effect on the 13th June 2020 came into force.
Businesses in which the main premises is closed, libraries, and places of worship can offer goods for sale or hire on a secondary premises, or by delivery when orders have been placed by phone/internet/post.
Businesses in which the main premises is closed, libraries, and places of worship can operate a café or restaurant on a secondary premises, to sell food and drink for consumption off the premises.
Community centres can open to host indoor markets.

description: The Scottish Government is telling businesses including cafes, pubs, and restaurants to close, along with nightclubs, theatres, cinemas, gyms, casinos, betting shops, bingo halls, concert halls, zoos and leisure centres from 20 March 2020. UPDATE: From 29 June outdoor areas of zoos and gardens will be able to open to the public, provided appropriate measures are put in place to ensure physical distancing and compliance. When re-opening, establishments will be strongly encouraged to use online and/or telephone ticket sales to control the number of people on site at any given time and only those who live in the local area (within five miles) should be visiting zoos until further notice.

description: On the 3rd July 2020, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions)(Leicester) Regulations 2020 were rushed through parliament. These regulations came into effect on the 4th July 2020. These regulations apply in relationship to England only, specifically the areas in and around the city of Leicester. This is the first local lockdown in the UK.All businesses in Leicester must close premises in which food or drink are sold for consumption on the premises. Businesses in Leicester selling non-food goods for sale or hire, or providing library services, must cease to carry on that business on their premises.

UPDATE: Hairdressers and barbers will permitted to re-open from 15 July with strict guidance. This guidance includes physical distancing with marked areas between seats and treatment stations, Perspex screens installed at workstations, bookings by appointment only with staggered times, the retention of customer details for four weeks, face coverings mandatory for staff and customers with visors recommended for staff and reading materials and refreshments removed other than water on request.

description: From 14 August 2020, it is mandatory for hospitality settings to collect the contact details of visitors to their premises in support of Test and Protect. The new regulations apply to restaurants, cafes, pubs and hotels in which food or drink are sold for consumption on the premises. These businesses must now record the name and contact number of an individual- or lead member of each  household in a group- that visit the premises. These regulations apply to customers, staff working on a particular day and visitors such as delivery drivers or cleaners. Premises must store the information for 21 days and share it when requested to do so by public health officers with 24 hours.

description: From the 23rd of September 2020, drink-only pubs and bars are allowed to reopen in Northern Ireland, UK. The Northern Ireland Executive has agreed on mandatory requirements for pubs opening, including table service only, dancing banned in hospitality venues, a maximum of 6 people from any number of households seated at a table. The venue will be required to collect customer details to assist with contact tracing. Face coverings should be worn to enter and leave the venue and for movement inside, however, they are not required once seated. Other safety measures include social distancing and hand sanitising stations.

description:
In the central belt areas of Scotland including Ayrshire & Arran, Forth Valley, Greater Glasgow & Clyde, Lanarkshire and Lothian, all licensed premises will be required to close except for takeaway. Unlicensed premises will be able to open between 6am and 6pm and evening meals may be served in accommodation for residents only but no alcohol can be served. Furthermore, adult group exercise classes for indoor venues, adult indoor or outdoor contact sports or training and outdoor live events will not be permitted. Snooker/pool halls, indoor bowling, casinos and bingo halls are to also close

In all other areas in Scotland, all hospitality premises that are not licensed to sell alcohol may only open indoors between 6am and 6pm where licensed premises may open outdoors until 10pm. 

The restrictions on licensed premises will come into effect 18:00 on the Oct 9, with all other restrictions coming into effect from 00:01 on the Oct 10.

description: From 14 August 2020, it is mandatory for hospitality settings to collect the contact details of visitors to their premises in support of Test and Protect. The new regulations apply to restaurants, cafes, pubs and hotels in which food or drink are sold for consumption on the premises. These businesses must now record the name and contact number of an individual- or lead member of each  household in a group- that visit the premises. These regulations apply to customers, staff working on a particular day and visitors such as delivery drivers or cleaners. Premises must store the information for 21 days and share it when requested to do so by public health officers with 24 hours. UPDATE: Under the new system set out by the Scottish Government, hospitality premises may sell alcohol indoors with a main meal up to 8pm at level two, enabling the service of an early evening meal. At present, hospitality premises outside the central belt cannot service alcohol indoors and must close indoors at 6pm. All hospitality premises will operate in the daytime, up to 6pm, without the sale of alcohol. Hotels and other accommodation will continue to be able to serve evening meals to residents. These will take effect from November 2nd.

description: Homeware stores and garden centres will close in all level 4 areas- which is a vast majority of Scotland- from Boxing Day with the exception of click and collect. Members of the public within level are also being urged to stay close to home where possible to help stop the spread of Coronavirus (COVID-19). This stricter definition of essential retailers and new stay at home message have been introduced to help tackle the new variant of the virus which can spread far more quickly and easily.

description: From 16 Jan 2021, non essential click and collet retail services will be prohibited in Level 4 areas and further changes will be put in place to how service open for essential purposes operate. Timeslots will be required for collection and people should not enter a store to collect an item. Businesses providing takeaway will also operate on a 'non-entry' basis only, meaning customer cannot enter the premises when placing or collecting orders. Restrictions banning the consumption of alcohol in public places will also be introduced. These new regulations apply to all parts of Scotland currently in lockdown and will come into effect at 00:01 on 16 Jan 2021. Click and Collect services offered by essential retailers can continue but will be suspended across retail other than for clothing and footwear stores, homeware stores, garden centres/plant nurseries, baby equipment shops, electrical goods (including repairs), key cutting and shore repair shops and bookstores

description:
Visiting to aged care homes is restricted to essential visitors. Essential visitors include appropriate health and care staff based on resident need, for a person receiving end-of-life care, to support someone with a mental health issues such as dementia, a learning disability or autism where not being present would cause the resident to be distressed. Alternatives to in-person visiting should be explored, such as the use of telephones or video calls. 

Where families and friends are permitted to visit to be with their loved one then anyone who is showing coronavirus symptoms should not visit. The number of visitors at the bedside at any given time is limited to one person or, where social distancing throughout the visit is possible, a second additional visitor could be permitted. Visitors must agree to wear appropriate PPE and follow any isolation/quarantine rules if necessary. Contact between visitors and other residents and staff should be minimised through only visiting and leaving the room directly and social distancing.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Accountant in Bankruptcy (AiB), Scotland's Insolvency Agency, has suspended sale and eviction from property until further notice from March 21 2020 in response to the current COVID-19 pandemic. 

New measures and greater flexibility are also being introduced by AiB to simplify procedures to help those seeking debt relief through bankruptcy, or need more time to pay their debts through the Debt Arrangement Scheme. This action will also help alleviate the administrative burden on front-line money advisers and insolvency practitioners.

description:
Visiting to aged care homes is restricted to essential visitors. Essential visitors include appropriate health and care staff based on resident need, for a person receiving end-of-life care, to support someone with a mental health issues such as dementia, a learning disability or autism where not being present would cause the resident to be distressed. Alternatives to in-person visiting should be explored, such as the use of telephones or video calls. 

Where families and friends are permitted to visit to be with their loved one then anyone who is showing coronavirus symptoms should not visit. The number of visitors at the bedside at any given time is limited to one person or, where social distancing throughout the visit is possible, a second additional visitor could be permitted. Visitors must agree to wear appropriate PPE and follow any isolation/quarantine rules if necessary. Contact between visitors and other residents and staff should be minimised through only visiting and leaving the room directly and social distancing. UPDATE: Care home residents will now be able to receive visitors outside from 3 July, provided their home meets strict criteria, with infection control measures remaining in place. The next phase of visiting will include outdoor meetings with a single nominated visitor and face coverings must be worn for the visit's duration. Currently, only essential visits, including those involving end of life care are permitted.

description:
Visiting to aged care homes is restricted to essential visitors. Essential visitors include appropriate health and care staff based on resident need, for a person receiving end-of-life care, to support someone with a mental health issues such as dementia, a learning disability or autism where not being present would cause the resident to be distressed. Alternatives to in-person visiting should be explored, such as the use of telephones or video calls. 

Where families and friends are permitted to visit to be with their loved one then anyone who is showing coronavirus symptoms should not visit. The number of visitors at the bedside at any given time is limited to one person or, where social distancing throughout the visit is possible, a second additional visitor could be permitted. Visitors must agree to wear appropriate PPE and follow any isolation/quarantine rules if necessary. Contact between visitors and other residents and staff should be minimised through only visiting and leaving the room directly and social distancing. UPDATE: Care home residents will be able to receive more outdoor visitors from the 10th of August. From this date, care home residents will be able to have up to three outdoor visitors from no more than two households provided their home meets strict criteria, with infection control measures remaining in place. A care home will only be able to permit visiting if they have been COVID-free throughout the pandemic or if all affected residents have fully recovered and no residents or staff have had symptoms for 28 days and the home is actively participating in weekly staff testing. Visitors will need to wear face coverings throughout their visit and physical distancing and had and cough hygiene will need to be adhered to at all times. 
Care home providers have also been asked to develop plans on how they can safely allow one designated indoor visitor for residents wither their homes. These plans must be submitted by August 24 and will be signed off by the relevant health board's Director of Public Health once they are satisfied with the plan and the home meets all criteria for indoor visiting.

description:
Following the advice from the UK and Scottish Governments on limiting social contact, the National Library of Scotland has closed all buildings to the public, including George IV Bridged and Causewayside in Edinburgh, and the National Library at Kelvin Hill in Glasgow as of June 24. All events planned to take place in Library buildings are cancelled for the foresseable future and Library members are now unable to order physical items. 

UPDATE: There will be limited reading room service at that National Library of Scotland''s George IV Bridge and Causewayside building in Edinburgh from August 11. Update as of 28 July states that these reading rooms in Edinburgh will be open to existing library card holders on a pre-booked basis. description:
Visiting to aged care homes is restricted to essential visitors. Essential visitors include appropriate health and care staff based on resident need, for a person receiving end-of-life care, to support someone with a mental health issues such as dementia, a learning disability or autism where not being present would cause the resident to be distressed. Alternatives to in-person visiting should be explored, such as the use of telephones or video calls. 

Where families and friends are permitted to visit to be with their loved one then anyone who is showing coronavirus symptoms should not visit. The number of visitors at the bedside at any given time is limited to one person or, where social distancing throughout the visit is possible, a second additional visitor could be permitted. Visitors must agree to wear appropriate PPE and follow any isolation/quarantine rules if necessary. Contact between visitors and other residents and staff should be minimised through only visiting and leaving the room directly and social distancing. UPDATE: Care home can resume face-to-face care from a wide range of health and social care professionals, including podiatrists, physiotherapists, optometrists, dentists, social workers and mental health and disability specialists from 7 September. This will also allow the safe resumption of activity in indoor communal areas- for example lounges and dinging areas- as long as strict heath and safety measures are in place. Enhanced visiting will only be resumed in care homes where there are not active cases, have been free of COVID-19 for 28 days, and are actively participating in the care home worker testing programs

description:
Following the advice from the UK and Scottish Governments on limiting social contact, the National Library of Scotland has closed all buildings to the public, including George IV Bridged and Causewayside in Edinburgh, and the National Library at Kelvin Hill in Glasgow as of June 24. All events planned to take place in Library buildings are cancelled for the foresseable future and Library members are now unable to order physical items. 

UPDATE: The National Library at Kelvin Hall will reopen on Tuesday 22 September. UPDATE: UPDATE: The National Library at Kelvin Hall will reopen on Tuesday 22 September with the opening hours will be 10:00-16:00 Tuesdays to Saturdays. Health and safety measures will be in place, in line with Scottish Government guidelines

description:
Visiting to aged care homes is restricted to essential visitors. Essential visitors include appropriate health and care staff based on resident need, for a person receiving end-of-life care, to support someone with a mental health issues such as dementia, a learning disability or autism where not being present would cause the resident to be distressed. Alternatives to in-person visiting should be explored, such as the use of telephones or video calls. 

Where families and friends are permitted to visit to be with their loved one then anyone who is showing coronavirus symptoms should not visit. The number of visitors at the bedside at any given time is limited to one person or, where social distancing throughout the visit is possible, a second additional visitor could be permitted. Visitors must agree to wear appropriate PPE and follow any isolation/quarantine rules if necessary. Contact between visitors and other residents and staff should be minimised through only visiting and leaving the room directly and social distancing. UPDATE: Updated guidance published by the Scottish Government recommends easing restrictions on visiting in a range of ways, including extending indoor visits from 30 minutes to up to four hours. Outdoor visits can be extended to include up to six visitors from no more than two households, including children and young people, for up to one hour per visit.
The new guidance also supports increased personal interaction, including hugs or hand holding, as long as strict PPE and infection prevention control measures are met. These include visitors can support personal care and daily routine activities, provided this is agreed with the care home and take places in residents' rooms, enabling contact with loved ones with regular training and supervision for visitors to put on and take off PPE and safety guidelines, family pets and therapy animals during outdoor and indoor visiting if agree with the care home and certain pre-conditions are met and gifts and residents' belongings can be brought in by visitors when agreed with the care home manager in advance.
