description:
New legislation has been published to ensure that Scotland's parliamentary election on May 6 can take place fairly and safely during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The poll is expected to go ahead as planned on May 6 and the Scottish General Election (Coronavirus) Bill has been drafted to provide powers, if needed, to conduct the election differently. The Bill introduces key measures including an earlier deadline for postal vote applications of April 6 rather April 20 to give more time for these to be processed given expected increase in demand and the power for Ministers to allow polling to take place over more than one day if needed to support physical distancing at polling stations.

Measures have also been included for the highly unlikely event that the election has to be deferred. The Bill therefore moves dissolution of parliament to May 5 rather March 25 to ensure MPs can pass emergency legislation to delay the election if required.

description: The number of criminal trails will be reduced by up to 75% as part of efforts to reduce the transmission of coronavirus (COVID-19). The Lord President has made it clear that all of Scotland's courts remain open and that all criminal jury trails in the High Court and Sheriff Court will continue. Remote juries will continue to play an important part i supporting access to justice. The reduction in the overall number of criminal trails taking place during lockdown by up to 75% will see fewer people moving to, from, and within court buildings.

description: Public health restrictions have significantly impacted the ability for unpaid work- the most common element of Community Payback Orders (CPOs)- to be undertaken safely. In response to the risk of community justice service being overwhelmed and the need to ensure existing order can be delivered safely within a reasonable timescale and new orders started, the Scottish Government is laying regulations to reduce the unpaid work element impose in existing CPOs by 35%, with the exception of those imposed for domestic abuse, sexual offence and stalking.

description: People struggling to secure or retain permanent employment can access free support delivered by trained advisors. The national employment service Fair Start Scotland provides personalised and tailored support to those who have struggled to find and stay in work due to their personal circumstances. This may include caring commitments, health conditions or disabilities or other challenges cause by long-term unemployment. A new marketing campaign has launched to ensure more people can access advice and support, including those who may be finding it more difficult to secure and retain employment as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.

description:
In England (UK), on 26th March, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020 came into effect. Places of worship must be closed, except for funerals, to broadcast an act of worship, or to provide essential voluntary services or urgent public support services.
Community centres must close, except to provide essential voluntary services or urgent public support services.
Crematoriums and burial grounds must close to members of the public, except for funerals or burials.
UPDATE: On the 1st June 2020 in England, UK, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (Amendment) (No. 3) Regulations 2020 came into force. Places of worship and community centres can open for the purposes of early years childcare.
 UPDATE: On the 1st June 2020 in England, UK, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (Amendment) (No. 3) Regulations 2020 came into force.  This states that places of worship and community centres can open for the purposes of early years childcare.

description: On the 3rd July 2020, The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions)(Leicester) Regulations 2020 were rushed through parliament. These regulations came into effect on the 4th July 2020. These regulations apply in relationship to England only, specifically the areas in and around the city of Leicester. This is the first local lockdown in the UK.No person may participate in a gathering in Leicester which takes place in a public or private place outdoors, and consists of more than six persons, or indoors, and consists of two or more persons, without reasonable excuse. People or businesses that repeatedly flout the new law could be fined up to £3,200 (£100 for first offence). Police are to enforce these restrictions. Fines are not imposed to people under 18 years old.

description:
On 4 June 2021, Wales (UK) announced that outdoor restrictions of mass gatherings will ease as COVID-19 alert levels alleviate (level 2 to 1). From 7 June 2021, residents can gather with members of their individual households without restrictions.

A maximum of 30 people (except children under 11) can meet outdoors, including private and public spaces such as gardens, parks, or beaches.

Additionally, a maximum of 30 people (except children under 11 or carers of these households) can meet outdoors in ‘regulated premises’ such as cafes, restaurants, bars and visitor attractions.

description:
From 7 August, Wales de-escalated Coronavirus alert levels to level 0. 

Restrictions on the number of people who can meet indoors, in public places or at events are removed.

All businesses and premises can open, including nightclubs.

Nevertheless, residents are advised to work from home whenever possible. Face coverings remain a legal requirement indoors, except for hospitality premises. 

Fully vaccinated adults, persons under 18 and vaccine trial participants need not self-isolate if they had close contact with coronavirus-infected people.

description:
Scotland is requiring all work on construction sites, unless it is for essential projects, should stop immediately as of April 6 2020, as outlined in new guidance for the construction industry. Any project deemed essential can only continue operating if it can comply with guidance on social distance, safety and welfare during the COVID-19 outbreak. Any site unable to meet these requirements should close. 

Essential projects include: those to create or re-purpose facilities which will be used directly in COVID-19 related activities, projects to create or re-purpose facilities which will be used to accommodate key workers, or free up space in facilities to be used directly in COVID-19 related activities. projects which are considered essential public services and the repair and maintenance of critical infrastructure

description: On the 10th of May 2020, the UK government released a document that stated that "the Government is now advising that people should aim to wear a face-covering in enclosed spaces where social distancing is not always possible and they come into contact with others that they do not normally meet, for example on public transport or in some shops... Face-coverings should not be used by children under the age of two, or those who may find it difficult to manage them correctly, for example primary age children unassisted, or those with respiratory conditions. It is important to use facecoverings properly and wash your hands before putting them on and taking them off". The government allowed people outdoors "subject to: not meeting up with any more than one person from outside your household; continuedcompliance with social distancing guidelines to remain two metres (6ft) away from people outsideyour household; good hand hygiene, particularly with respect to shared surfaces".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Visiting to aged care homes is restricted to essential visitors. Essential visitors include appropriate health and care staff based on resident need, for a person receiving end-of-life care, to support someone with a mental health issues such as dementia, a learning disability or autism where not being present would cause the resident to be distressed. Alternatives to in-person visiting should be explored, such as the use of telephones or video calls. 

Where families and friends are permitted to visit to be with their loved one then anyone who is showing coronavirus symptoms should not visit. The number of visitors at the bedside at any given time is limited to one person or, where social distancing throughout the visit is possible, a second additional visitor could be permitted. Visitors must agree to wear appropriate PPE and follow any isolation/quarantine rules if necessary. Contact between visitors and other residents and staff should be minimised through only visiting and leaving the room directly and social distancing. UPDATE: Care home residents will now be able to receive visitors outside from 3 July, provided their home meets strict criteria, with infection control measures remaining in place. The next phase of visiting will include outdoor meetings with a single nominated visitor and face coverings must be worn for the visit's duration. Currently, only essential visits, including those involving end of life care are permitted.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From 15 July 2020, there will be exemptions to the 2m social distancing rule in Scotland for public transport, retail and hospitality sectors to allow a move from 2m to 1m physical distancing. For the purpose of this guidance, hospitality sectors relates to public houses, restaurants and cafes, including those where they are situated within other premises, such as hotels, visitor attractions and clubs.

description:
Visiting to aged care homes is restricted to essential visitors. Essential visitors include appropriate health and care staff based on resident need, for a person receiving end-of-life care, to support someone with a mental health issues such as dementia, a learning disability or autism where not being present would cause the resident to be distressed. Alternatives to in-person visiting should be explored, such as the use of telephones or video calls. 

Where families and friends are permitted to visit to be with their loved one then anyone who is showing coronavirus symptoms should not visit. The number of visitors at the bedside at any given time is limited to one person or, where social distancing throughout the visit is possible, a second additional visitor could be permitted. Visitors must agree to wear appropriate PPE and follow any isolation/quarantine rules if necessary. Contact between visitors and other residents and staff should be minimised through only visiting and leaving the room directly and social distancing. UPDATE: Care home residents will be able to receive more outdoor visitors from the 10th of August. From this date, care home residents will be able to have up to three outdoor visitors from no more than two households provided their home meets strict criteria, with infection control measures remaining in place. A care home will only be able to permit visiting if they have been COVID-free throughout the pandemic or if all affected residents have fully recovered and no residents or staff have had symptoms for 28 days and the home is actively participating in weekly staff testing. Visitors will need to wear face coverings throughout their visit and physical distancing and had and cough hygiene will need to be adhered to at all times. 
Care home providers have also been asked to develop plans on how they can safely allow one designated indoor visitor for residents wither their homes. These plans must be submitted by August 24 and will be signed off by the relevant health board's Director of Public Health once they are satisfied with the plan and the home meets all criteria for indoor visiting.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

UPDATE: Care home can resume face-to-face care from a wide range of health and social care professionals, including podiatrists, physiotherapists, optometrists, dentists, social workers and mental health and disability specialists from 7 September. This will also allow the safe resumption of activity in indoor communal areas- for example lounges and dinging areas- as long as strict heath and safety measures are in place. Enhanced visiting will only be resumed in care homes where there are not active cases, have been free of COVID-19 for 28 days, and are actively participating in the care home worker testing programs

description: From the 23rd of September 2020, drink-only pubs and bars are allowed to reopen in Northern Ireland, UK. The Northern Ireland Executive has agreed on mandatory requirements for pubs opening, including table service only, dancing banned in hospitality venues, a maximum of 6 people from any number of households seated at a table. The venue will be required to collect customer details to assist with contact tracing. Face coverings should be worn to enter and leave the venue and for movement inside, however, they are not required once seated. Other safety measures include social distancing and hand sanitising stations.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Bars

description:
Visiting to aged care homes is restricted to essential visitors. Essential visitors include appropriate health and care staff based on resident need, for a person receiving end-of-life care, to support someone with a mental health issues such as dementia, a learning disability or autism where not being present would cause the resident to be distressed. Alternatives to in-person visiting should be explored, such as the use of telephones or video calls. 

Where families and friends are permitted to visit to be with their loved one then anyone who is showing coronavirus symptoms should not visit. The number of visitors at the bedside at any given time is limited to one person or, where social distancing throughout the visit is possible, a second additional visitor could be permitted. Visitors must agree to wear appropriate PPE and follow any isolation/quarantine rules if necessary. Contact between visitors and other residents and staff should be minimised through only visiting and leaving the room directly and social distancing. UPDATE: Updated guidance published by the Scottish Government recommends easing restrictions on visiting in a range of ways, including extending indoor visits from 30 minutes to up to four hours. Outdoor visits can be extended to include up to six visitors from no more than two households, including children and young people, for up to one hour per visit.
The new guidance also supports increased personal interaction, including hugs or hand holding, as long as strict PPE and infection prevention control measures are met. These include visitors can support personal care and daily routine activities, provided this is agreed with the care home and take places in residents' rooms, enabling contact with loved ones with regular training and supervision for visitors to put on and take off PPE and safety guidelines, family pets and therapy animals during outdoor and indoor visiting if agree with the care home and certain pre-conditions are met and gifts and residents' belongings can be brought in by visitors when agreed with the care home manager in advance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other government service not specified above
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Visiting to adult care homes will be limited to one designated visitor allowed to visit with a adult care home resident in an outdoor setting. Essential indoor visiting will be allowed under specific circumstances and with the appropriate precautions in place. UPDATE: Outdoor visiting will no include no more than 6 people from two separate households at the same time per person for approximately one hour once a week. This is provided that physical distancing is still possible and facilities allow. Children and young people under the ago of 18 can only visit outdoors.

Indoor visiting will be limited to one designated person for up to 4 hours once a week (not including essential visiting).

Family and loved ones may also continue to visit residents in any care home who are bed bound or otherwise not fit to go outside at their window. This window visiting will need to be scheduled to ensure that the risks from increased footfall are mitigated and residents can be supported.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
The wearing of face coverings is to become mandatory in communal workplace areas, such as corridors, canteens and social spaces. The wearing of face coverings in a workplace canteen, when not seated at a table, such as when queuing, entering or leaving the canteen (in line with other hospitality venues) from the 16th October. The wearing of face coverings in other indoor communal workplaces, such as corridors and social space from 19th October. 
There will be an exemption for couples during their indoor marriage ceremony or civil partnership registration, providing there is a partition or 2 metres can be maintained between the couple and other people

description: The Scottish Government has produced a face covering exemption card, to support those who are unable to wear one to feel more confident and safe when accessing public spaces and using public services. Everyone who can do so is legally obliged to wear a face covering where it is mandated by law, but, the face covering exemption card is available to people who cannot, due to health conditions, disabilities or other special circumstances where a face covering may cause difficult or distress. A physical card can be requested from Disability Equality Scotland, while a digital card is also available to be displayed on a phone, tablet or other device. Physical and digital cards are available to required online from October 29

description:
Across all levels of restrictions, face coverings should be worn by adults at all times where they cannot keep two metres from other adults and/or children and young people in primary and secondary schools (with some exceptions in P1-2). Face coverings should also be worn by parents and other visitors to any school site (whether entering the building or otherwise), including parents at drop-off and pick-up
In Local Authority Areas in Levels 3 and 4, pupils in the senior phase- S4-5- and their teachers should wear face coverings in classrooms, as well as when they are moving around the school and in communal areas.

description:
In the UK, from 19 July 2021, masks are no longer required at the national level. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has urged caution as most legal restrictions on social contact are lifted in England.

There are now no limits on how many people can meet or attend events, nightclubs reopened at midnight, and table service will not be necessary in pubs and restaurants.

Face coverings will be recommended in some spaces, but not required by law.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In Wales, the UK, some restrictions are still in place in elderly care homes following 7 August 2021 but are much less stringent than the previous policy. Version 10 of the guidance supersedes previous versions. The key changes are:    To introduce ‘essential visitors’. Each resident can now nominate an essential visitor. The essential visitor may visit the resident regularly indoors during a COVID-19 outbreak at the care home provided the resident or visitor does not themselves have COVID-19 (unless there are exceptional circumstances). This will ensure that people can continue to benefit from regular visits by a nominated essential visitor when wider restrictions on routine visits may be in place. To remove the limit of two indoor visitors at the same time per resident. This will now be subject to a risk assessment by the care home.  To remove the need for visitors to wear face coverings in outdoor areas of the care home.   To amend requirements on the use of face coverings in indoor areas.   To clarify that indoor visits can take place in residents’ rooms as well as in a designated visiting space.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In Wales, from 24 May 2021, anyone can arrange a visit, with two people allowed to attend at the same time. However this is subject to a negative Covid test, and while relatives can hold hands with their loved ones, strict safety measures remain in place. The Welsh government said the "ultimate decision on whether, and in what circumstances care home visits take place, rests with the individual provider".
